Festival welcomes Paul McCartney to Louisville

The To Sir With Love festival welcomes Paul McCartney to Louisville with a celebration of his music.

Festival welcomes Paul McCartney to Louisville

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, jpuckett@courier-journal.com 7:34 a.m. EDT October 23, 2014

Paul McCartney’s “Out There” tour comes to the KFC Yum! Center on Oct. 28. (Photo: MJ Kim )

Story Highlights

  • To Sir With Love is a music festival that celebrates Paul McCartney.
  • The festival is produced by Gary Jacob of Abbey Road on the River, Louisville's annual Beatles fest.
  • McCartney has never performed in Louisville.
  • Mayor Greg Fischer has declared Oct. 22-28 as "Sir Paul McCartney Week."
632 CONNECT 44 TWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE

Gary Jacob is the founder of Louisville's Abbey Road on the River, the nation's largest Beatles festival, so it's a bit of an understatement to call him a big Sir Paul McCartney fan.

But when McCartney first announced that his "Out There" tour was coming to Louisville, Jacob had decidedly mixed feelings. McCartney's initial announced date, June 26, was only a couple of weeks after Abbey Road on the River, which presented two conflicts.

Beatles fans on a budget would almost certainly pick the concert over the festival, Jacob reasoned, and the timing made it awkward to create any tie-ins. But then McCartney got sick, forcing the Louisville show to be rescheduled and Jacob saw opportunity.

Beginning Friday, he will stage To Sir With Love, a mini-Macca festival dedicated to McCartney that culminates with his show Tuesday night at the KFC Yum! Center.

"Our original concept was to do as much as we can to honor him because we, as Abbey Road on the River, actually feel a responsibility," he said. "As soon as he switched the dates, we knew we had to do something. It's important to our brand, and it's important to celebrate the guy."

Jeffrey Lee and Tom look at the Top 10 Paul McCartney solo songs of all time.

McCartney has never performed in Louisville, and he'll arrive to discover that Mayor Greg Fischer has declared Oct. 22-28 to be "Sir Paul McCartney Week."

Events include a free concert Oct. 28 at 4th Street Live from 2 to 7 p.m. with The Rigbys and the Nick Peay Band, and Louisville will stage a Meat Free Monday, a cause promoted by McCartney, Oct. 27.

DREAM A DREAM: Susan Boyle brings her fairy-tale success to KCA

Jacob's festival runs Friday through Sunday at the Galt House Hotel and will feature 10 artists, 20 performances and a panel discussion about McCartney's influence, featuring Denny Laine, Laurence Juber, Steve Holley, all of whom performed in Wings, and Terry Sylvester of The Hollies. A detailed schedule is available at www.arotr.com.

To Sir With Love is far smaller than AROTR, which draws 30,000 fans over Memorial Day Weekend, but will feature several of the same performers, including BritBeat, Sixty Four, Jukebox and Johnny Heywood. Laine, Juber and Holley will perform a set dedicated to the best of Wings, Juber will do a solo show and Sylvester is bringing his band, The Cryers.

The entire festival will be confined to a Galt House ballroom with a capacity of 600.

"We never did intend for it to be huge," Jacob said. "The music is just as good, but you don't have to run around from stage to stage. A lot of people enjoy that."

There is one other musician Jacob is hoping will stop by: the titular Sir Paul. McCartney performs Saturday in Jacksonville, and Jacob's dream scenario has him arriving in Louisville on Sunday and stopping by the Galt House. Invitations have been extended through management, so why not?

"We've had fantasies," Jacob said. "If he stops by our place, great, but we don't really have any expectations. But we'd love to get him to go to the (Muhammad) Ali Center, and maybe pose for a picture next to the photo of Ali with The Beatles. That would just be a home run."

Jeffrey Lee Puckett can be reached at (502) 582-4160, jpuckett@courier-journal.com and on Twitter, @JLeePuckett.

TO SIR WITH LOVE

WHEN: Friday, 6-11 p.m.; Saturday, 3 p.m.-midnight; Sunday, noon-10 p.m.

WHERE: Galt House Hotel, Ballroom C, 140 N. Fourth St.

COST: $20 general admission, $30 reserved seating Friday (must be purchased online at www.arotr.com); $29 general admission, $59 reserved seating Saturday and Sunday. GA is $20 at the door after 6 p.m. on Saturday and Sunday, and half-off specials for reserved seating are available online through Oct. 24 for Saturday and Sunday. Ages 21 and under are always $10 at the door for GA, $15 for reserved.

To Sir with Love is sponsored by WAKY 103.1 and Gretsch Guitars.

PAUL McCARTNEY 'OUT THERE' TOUR

WHEN: 8 p.m. Oct. 28

WHERE: KFC Yum! Center

COST: $29.50, $59.50, $89.50, $170, $256, available at the box office, online at www.ticketmaster.com and by phone, (800) 745-3000
